question: Morning, Floyd. Top o' the morning, Mr. President.
answer: Morning, Kenny. You see this goddamn Capehart stuff?

question: Bayh's going to lose, but it's good groundwork for us for '64.
answer: I was eating that.

question: No you weren't.
answer: I was, you bastard. So what've we got today?

question: Today, for your information, is Pulaski Day. We're going to Buffalo... Who else you got? Got the touch? Everyone likes a good kid...
answer: How's my favorite President?

question: Busy. But you've got his heart.
answer: I want an hour with him.

question: I said his heart, not his attention.
answer: Three weeks before midterm elections? You need me.

question: Well. There is a new civil rights initiative he wants to talk about.
answer: I'm doing a piece on Skybolt. I hear Macmillan's meeting with him in Nassau.

question: We're giving the Brits Polaris instead. But a story'll just aggravate things. Not today. He's got tight schedule.
answer: Pretending there isn't a problem won't fix it. He can clear the air on Anglo American relations.

question: Forget it, Scotty.
answer: Let him talk to me, he makes Macmillan look good, I print it, the British public likes it, Macmillan owes you.

question: Hey, Mac. You're up bright and early.
answer: No, Ken. I need to see him now...

question: Morning, Floyd. What's it about?
answer: Cuba.

question: Listen to me, you worthless piece of disloyal shit. You will pull Daly's man on the circuit. You owe your goddamn job to this administration. There is a word you need to learn. It is the only word in politics. Loyalty. LOYALTY you motherfucking piece of shit! What're you looking at? This isn't the blessed order of St. Mary the Meek. Excuse us.
answer: I think you should come in here. Still think Cuba isn't important?

question: Not as far as the election goes.
answer: You used to look down a bomb sight for a living, Ken. What do you see?

question: Good. Good.
answer: Where the hell are you?

question: In here!
answer: Jesus Christ, guys. What the hell's Khruschev thinking?

question: Did you have any indication of this from Georgi? Any possible warning or sense of motivation?
answer: Complete snowjob. And then we went out and told the country they weren't putting missiles into Cuba. By the way, you realize we just lost the midterms.

question: The other thing is...
answer: ... I know. CIA and the military fucked us on the Bay of Pigs.

question: They're going to be pressing for a military solution soon. We can't afford to let them ram their agenda down our throats. We need to come with options other than air strikes so we have some sort of choice here.
answer: We got a bunch of smart guys. We lock 'em up together in there, kick 'em in the ass til they come up with options. I'll do it.

question: It's too politicized with you in there, anyway. They need to be able to stick their necks out.
answer: It'll be the principals, a couple of the key guys from each department

question: Sir.
answer: What is it?

question: The number you asked for.
answer: I ask for a lot of 'em. Whose is it?

question: Dean Acheson's, sir.
answer: Gotta go, Scotty. See you tomorrow.

question: We have high confidence in the expanded air strike option. The problem, Mr. President, is that it's a short-term solution. Khruschev can send more missiles next month. The Chiefs and I believe we should follow up the air strikes with the full version of
answer: An invasion...

question: Yes, sir. We can be sure we get all the missiles, and we remove Castro so this can never happen again.
answer: Is this the Chiefs' recommendation?

question: Yes, sir. Our best option is to commence the strikes before the missiles are operational. The invasion happens eight days later.
answer: Dean. What do you think?

question: Jesus Christ Almighty... Call me Irish, but I don't believe in cooler heads prevailing.
answer: Acheson's scenario is unacceptable. And he has more experience than anyone.

question: There is no expert on this subject, no wise old man.
answer: The thing is, Acheson's right. Talk alone won't accomplish anything.

question: Kenny! What happened? They didn't let me up front, said the President was on the phone the whole time.
answer: He was.

question: Yeah? Who was he talking to? Acheson? Come on, O'Donnell, everyone's wondering what's going on. What's Acheson doing in town? And don't give me some bullshit about DNC think tanks. Acheson's Mr. Cold War.
answer: Why don't you ask him yourself? You can have him on the way home.

question: Mr. President, the motto I chose for SAC is 'Peace is our Profession.' God forbid we find ourselves in a nuclear exchange. But if launched, those missiles in Cuba would kill a lot of Americans. That's why I'm being such a pain in the ass about destroying them. Destroying them immediately. Hell, even Mac agrees.
answer: General, what will the Soviets do when we attack?

question: Nothing.
answer: Nothing?

question: Nothing. Because the only alternative open to them is one they can't choose.
answer: Those aren't just missiles we'll be destroying. We kill Soviet soldiers, and they will respond. How would we respond if they killed ours? No, they will do something, General, I promise you that. And I believe it'll be Berlin.

question: So that there should be no misunderstanding, the position of the United States, which has been made clear by the Attorney General to Ambassador Dobrynin here, I shall read a sentence from my own statement to the press dated September 13th. Should missiles or offensive weapons be placed in Cuba, it would present the gravest threat to U.S. national security. So I do not misunderstand you
answer: What happened?

question: Lying bastard. Lied to my face.
answer: We're split down the middle. If I held a vote I think airstrike would beat blockade by a vote or two.

question: I want a consensus, Bobby. Consensus. Either air strike or blockade. Something everyone'll stand by even if they don't like it. I need it by Saturday. Make it happen.
answer: What if I can't?

question: We go into this split, the Russians will know it. And they'll use it against us.
answer: Have you cancelled Chicago and the rest of the weekend yet?

question: You don't show for Chicago, everyone'll know there's something going on.
answer: I don't care. Cancel it.

question: No way. I'm not calling and cancelling on Daly. You call and cancel on Daly.
answer: You're scared to cancel on Daly.

question: Damn right I'm scared.
answer: Well, I'm not.

question: Kenny, all right. What's going on here? There's rumors going around an exercise in the southeast is related to Cuba. I'm the Press Secretary. I can't do my job if I don't know what's going on. So what's going on?
answer: What are you telling them?

question: The truth
answer: Tell 'em you've looked into it, and all it is is an exercise. And Pierre -- The President may have a cold tomorrow.

question: There are major rail disruptions in the South, two airborne divisions are on alert. That exercise is an invasion.
answer: Well, you know how Bobby has it in for the State of Mississippi.

question: This is about Cuba.
answer: Cuba? You're fucking crazy. We are not invading Cuba. Nobody gives a rat's ass about Cuba. Not now, not ever. If you print something like that, all you're going to do is inflame the situation. Nobody talks to assholes who inflame situations. Assholes like that can find themselves cut out of the loop.

question: You've never threatened me before. All right. I'm not going to print anything until I have another source. But I promise you, I'll get one.
answer: Tell Pierre I need to talk to him. Bobby?

question: I don't think that's possible, Adlai. I will be asking the networks for air time Monday night. I have not yet made my final decision. We will announce our course of action then. I want to thank you all for your advice, gentlemen.
answer: Goddman Stevenson. Jesus. Peace at any price. You'd think nobody learned anything from World War Two.

question: Somebody had to say it. I respect Adlai for having the guts to risk looking like an appeaser.
answer: We have to pull him. He's not going to be able to handle the Soviets in front of the U.N. Zorin will eat him alive.

question: They want this fucking job, they can have it. It's no great joy to me. The elected representatives of the people have spoken... Now let's tell the people...
answer: Kenny stands there in the doorway, arms folded. As we PULL AWAY FROM HIM, we REVEAL the three NETWORK T.V. CAMERAS staring straight at us. Their red lights go on as one, and we swing around REVERSING TO:

question: Good evening, my fellow citizens. This Government, as promised, has maintained the closest surveillance of the Soviet military build-up on the island of Cuba... ...unmistakable evidence has now established the fact that a series of missile sites is in preparation on that imprisoned island. The purpose of these bases can be none other than to proved a nuclear strike capability against the Western Hemisphere... Therefore, in the defense of our own security and under the authority of the Constitution, I have directed that the following initial steps be taken. First, to halt this offensive build-up, a strict quarantine -- -- on all offensive military equipment under shipment to Cuba is being initiated. All ships of any kind bound for Cuba, if found to contain cargoes of offensive weapons, will be turned back. Second -- I have directed the Armed Forces to prepare for any eventualities.
answer: A beat. And the President looks up from his notes.

question: Then we fire at its rudder, disable it, and carry out the inspection.
answer: There will be no shooting without my explicit orders. Is that understood?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Well, Admiral, it looks like it's up to the Navy.

question: The Navy won't let you down, sir.
answer: General, have we developed any more information on the missiles?

question: I don't like what's happening.
answer: In the morning I'm taking charge of the blockade from the situation room. McNamara'll set up shop in the flag plot at the Pentagon, keep an eye on things there.

question: All right. 'Cause you get armed boarders climbing into Soviet ships, shots being fired across bows...
answer: I know, I know...

question: What about these low-level flights? They're starting in what? An hour? Do you realize what you're letting yourself in for?
answer: We need those flights. We have to know when those missiles become operational, because when they do, we need to destroy them.

question: Fair enough. But Castro's on alert and we're flying attack planes over their sites, on the deck. There's no way for them to know they're carrying cameras, not bombs. They're going to be shot at, plain and simple. I'm your political advisor, and I'm giving you political analysis here. This is a setup. The Chiefs want to go in. It's the only way they can redeem themselves for the Bay of Pigs. They have to go in, and they have to do it right. It's that simple.
answer: I'm gonna protect those pilots.

question: They're boxing us in with these rules of engagement. If you agree to 'em, and one of our planes gets knocked down or one of the ships won't stop for inspection, the Chiefs will have us by the balls and will force us to start shooting. They want a war, and they're arranging things to get one. If you don't want one, we have to do something about it.
answer: How does a man get to a place where he can say, 'throw those lives away,' so easily?

question: Maybe it's harder for them to say it than they let on. At the very least, they believe it's in our best interest. And at the end of the day, they may end up being right.
answer: Triple check everything the Chiefs say to us with the guys who actually have to do it. No one's to know about this but Bobby. I need redundant control over what happens out there. And if things aren't as advertised, you're going to make sure they come out the way I want them to come out, starting with this low level flight thing.

question: That's going to be tough. You know how these guys are about their chains of command...
answer: Any problems, you remind them those chains of commands end at one place. Me.

question: Any problems, you remind them those chains of commands end at one place. Me.
answer: Mr. President. The OAS meeting starts in an hour. I haven't prepared at all. We can't expect --

question: -- we need this one, Dean. The quarantine's legal if we get a mandate, otherwise it's an act of war in the eyes of the world. Get me that vote. Make it unanimous.
answer: Mr. President, The Organization of American States hasn't had a unanimous vote since --

question: Okay, Mr. O'Donnell. We'll do what we can. Get that fuel assayed?
answer: Yeah. It sucks. Ain't for high performance babies like ours. Shoulda brought some from home, but what can you do? Last-second deployments...

question: Okay, time to play Spin the Bottle with our bearded buddy. Nobody gets out ahead. Remember, just sitting here we're only ten minutes from target. Go to military throttle on my mark. Three...two...one... mark. Get some altitude! Affirmative. You two get out of here. Start your camera checks.
answer: That's alright, Lenny, it happens to most men at some time --

question: -- Scrub, you two. Get out of here. Still with me, Bruce?
answer: That's affirm.

question: Warm 'em up. We're here.
answer: Holy shit!

question: When are you going to be home?
answer: I don't know, Helen. I want you to keep the kids close tomorrow. Leave the T.V. on, sleep with it on in the bedroom until I tell you you can turn it off.

question: What's happened?
answer: Nothing. Nothing you don't know about. Tomorrow's the big day. Just have the car ready to go if I call or if the Civil Defense Warning comes on.

question: What happens to you? I'm not leaving without you.
answer: I'll be evacuated with the President.

question: Great. So while you're under a rock somewhere with the President, what am I supposed to do with your five children?
answer: I'll find you. But we're not going to let it come to that. I promise. Helen just asked me what sort of arrangements we have for the families.

question: Captain, force the sub to the surface for inspection.
answer: Mr. President! We're receiving reports that the ships are stopping!

question: Captain, belay that order! Bob, where's that coming from!
answer: Just a second, Mr. President.

question: Then let's move the quarantine line.
answer: Mr. President. Bobby. Kenny. The Essex battle group has the Gagarin, Kimovsk and the sub escort under their thumb. We've got a few hours now before we need to worry about any more flashpoints on the line. We could use a few more hours. I think we should consider moving the quarantine line back to 500 miles.

question: Moving the line. Stroke of genius.
answer: Of course it is. But the President needs to realize we're going to have to stop a ship eventually.

question: The Chiefs are looking for a provocation out there. The President's going to come under enormous pressure. You have to keep 'em on a short leash, Bob.
answer: You must think I'm blind and stupid. I've already gotten the birds and bees from Bobby. The President doesn't have to double-barrel me.

question: Listen to me, goddamn it. We're talking about a possible nuclear war. You dropped the ball on Bay of Pigs --
answer: -- you sonofabitch, goddamn it, I didn't drop --

question: You were in the room. It was your purview. It was your job to make sure Bissel wasn't fucking us over and you didn't do it. You've got the most important job in the world right now. You're the smartest guy the President has. Besides me.
answer: Anybody ever tell you you're an egomaniac and a prick, O'Donnell?

question: -- how the goddamn hell did this happen? I'm going to have Power's head on a platter next to LeMay's! Hey, Kenny, did you hear me give the order to go to DEFCON 2? I remember giving the order to go to DEFCON 3, but I must be suffering from amnesia because I've just been informed our nuclear forces are DEFCON 2!
answer: Mr. President, the orders were limited to our strategic forces in the continental U.S. Technically, General LeMay is correct that SAC has the statutory authority --

question: -- I have the authority. I am the commander-in-chief of the United States, and I say when we go to war!
answer: We are not at war, sir, not until we're at DEFCON 1.

question: What did you think of Lippman's column this morning?
answer: I think it's a bad idea.

question: Thank God. Look, everyone is furious about it. We trade away our missiles in Turkey and we're fucked politically. You gotta stop 'em. We know it's Jack and Bobby's idea - they leaked it to Lippman. The military guys are going ape, and they're not alone.
answer: Then they should speak up.

question: Christ, Ken, you know it's not that easy.
answer: Yes it is.

question: No it isn't. They don't trust the people that feel this way. But these people are right. And the Kennedys are wrong. We need you to tell 'em, Kenny. They'll listen to you. Jack and Bobby are good men. But it takes a certain character, moral toughness to stand up to --
answer: -- You listen to me. Nobody, nobody, talks about my friends that way. You're fucking here right now because of the Kennedys. They may be wrong. They make mistakes. But they're not weak. The weak ones are these 'people' who can't speak their own minds.

question: You know I don't mean they're weak.
answer: No, they just lack 'moral toughness.' And you think I'll play your Judas. You WASPS and blue-bloods never understood us, thinking we want into your club. Well we got our own club now. And you guys don't realize fighting with each other is our way. Nobody plays us off each other. And nobody ever gets between us...

question: No, they just lack 'moral toughness.' And you think I'll play your Judas. You WASPS and blue-bloods never understood us, thinking we want into your club. Well we got our own club now. And you guys don't realize fighting with each other is our way. Nobody plays us off each other. And nobody ever gets between us...
answer: What's that?

question: Oh, just a bunch of crap about withdrawing our Jupiter missiles in Turkey if the Soviets'll do the same in Cuba.
answer: I don't want to listen to this again.

question: If we made a trade, we'd be giving in to extortion, and NATO would never trust us again. We'll get clobbered in world opinion.
answer: It's a goddman trial balloon. Trial is the operative word, here.

question: Then somebody'd better deny it publicly.
answer: Jesus Christ, O'Donnell, you're the one saying we need to move forward on a political solution.

question: Yeah, a good political solution.
answer: You want to turn up the heat? You call Adlai. Tell him to stick it to Zorin.

question: Adlai's too weak! We have to convince Jack to pull him, get McCloy in there.
answer: You can't take him out this late in the game.

question: Zorin will eat him alive!
answer: Then talk to your brother, goddamn it. The two of you don't need any advice to get into trouble.

question: What's gotten into you? Oh, still sore about this.
answer: Something your father would've come up with.

question: My father --
answer: -- I'm just trying to make a point. This idea is that fucking bad. Adlai can handle Zorin. He knows the inning and the score.

question: We're kidding ourselves...
answer: Very well. Load your guns.

question: What was that, Admiral?
answer: We've been hailing the Groznyy for the last hour, Mr. Secretary. The Groznyy refuses to stop.

question: What are you doing?
answer: Carrying out our mission, Mr. Secretary. If you don't mind, we're very busy right now. We need to be able to do our jobs.

question: Admiral, I asked you a question.
answer: We're going to follow the Rules of Engagement. The Rules of Engagement which the President has approved and signed in his order of October 23rd. Yes, Captain, you may proceed. Clear your guns.

question: That ship was firing starshells. Starshells. Flares, Mr. Secretary. Goddammitt, I've got a job to do. You've been camped out up there since Monday night. You're exhausted and you're making mistakes. Interfere with me, you will get some of killed. I will not allow that.
answer: Starshells.

question: Get out of our way, Mr. Secretary. The navy has been running blockades since the days of John Paul Jones.
answer: I believe the President made it clear that there would be no firing on ships without his express permission.

question: With all due respect, Mr. Secretary, we were not firing on the ship. Firing on a ship means attacking the ship. We were not attacking the ship. We were firing over it.
answer: This was not the President's intention when he gave that order. What if the Soviets don't see the distention? What if they make the same mistake I just did? There will be no firing anything near ANY Soviet ships without my express permission, is that understood, Admiral?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: And I will only issue such instructions when ordered to by the President. John Paul Jones... you don't understand a thing, do you, Admiral? This isn't a blockade. This, all this, is language, a new vocabulary the likes of which the world has never seen. This is President Kennedy communicating with Secretary Khruschev.

question: The alternative, Mr. President, is that this could be a trap.
answer: Dangle a settlement, tie us down in negotiations, we come up short...

question: Why else would they approach us in this way? It's deniable. The Soviets have done nothing but lie to us. This could be more of the same.
answer: That may be why Khruschev's introducing this guy. We've been burned by his usual players in the formal channels, so he brings in an honest broker.

question: Kenny, get over to your old stomping grounds. Go through everything the FBI has on Fomin. I need your best call
answer: Who's he talking for? Is it Khruschev, or is this more bullshit? How do you become the KGB top spy in the United States? Politics is politics. Walter. Khruschev is the Moscow Party Boss under Stalin. Give me their career chronologies! Every time Khruschev moves up, Fomin does within a year... Khruschev was the administrator in charge of preparing Moscow's defenses during the war. And Fomin... was here in the U.S. They know each other. They're war buddies. Hello?

question: I've got to move. What do you have, Kenny?
answer: They know each other! Khruschev and Feklisov aka Fomin were war buddies!

question: You're sure...
answer: Don't take it to court, but we've got good circumstantial evidence... Walter agrees. My gut's telling me Khruschev's turning to a trusted old friend to carry his message.

question: I am instructed to tell you that the American Government would respond favorably to an offer along the lines you have discussed. If this solution were raised at the U.N. by Ambassador Zorin, he would find a favorable reply from Ambassador Stevenson.
answer: So I understand you correctly. If the missiles in Cuba were dismantled, returned to the Soviet Union, and a guarantee was made not to reintroduce them, the United States would be prepared to guarantee that it would never invade Cuba?

question: That is correct.
answer: This is from the Highest Authority?

question: Yes. From the Highest Authority. There are two conditions. The U.N. must be allowed to inspect the removal of the missiles.
answer: And, of course, the U.N. must be allowed to observe the redeployment of forces from the American Southeast. And the second condition?

question: Time is of the essence.
answer: John. How much time?

question: Where've you been? We've been trying to find you all morning.
answer: Helen and I went out for breakfast. EXCOM's not supposed to convene til eight.

question: We just got a second letter from Khruschev. The deal's off. We're getting everyone together as fast as we can.
answer: What does the letter say?

question: Hello? Anyone there?
answer: Major, my name is Kenneth O'Donnell. Special Assistant to the President. Major, a few days ago the President ordered me to help him keep control of what's going on out there. I've been browbeating pilots, navy guys left and right to make sure you don't get us here in Washington into trouble. But you know what? We're pretty damn good at getting ourselves into trouble. So instead of riding your ass, I'm just going to tell you what's going on, and let you figure out how best to help us out up here.

question: Go ahead, sir.
answer: Last night, we looked like we were going to cut a deal to get us all out of this mess. Today, the Soviets are reneging. We're going to try to salvage the situation, but a lot of things are going wrong today. It's making everyone nervous, and it will be very hard to avoid going to war. Don't get shot down, Major. Beyond that, whatever else you can do to help us, I'd really appreciate it.

question: Hey! Dad!
answer: Hey, sport. You winning?

question: Yeah. Is everything going to be okay, Dad?
answer: Yeah, Kev. Everything's gonna be fine.

question: I guess you won't be coming home tonight.
answer: I, uh...

question: Back to work. If we're going to make a deal, we're going to have to do it fast. This is only getting out of control. The only reason we're not at war this very minute is he's been able to stretch, bend and break his own rules. He won't be able to keep it up forever.
answer: And?

question: And Jack wants to trade the missiles in Turkey.
answer: The Jupiters are obsolete. They were supposed to have been dismantled last summer anyway --

question: -- Jesus, Mary and Joseph. I told you how stupid it was to float the Lippman article! But you wouldn't listen to me. What if there hasn't been a coup at all? What if it's you two who invited that second letter by raising the possibility of a trade? And if the two of you are thinking this trade is your ace in the hole, you're so wrong. It's a deuce. And it's not just me who thinks that. Everyone on this so-called EXCOM is telling you exactly the same thing
answer: All right, so maybe we overestimated how reasonable this trade would look. Okay? You happy? So now what?

question: So now you've got to talk him out of it. And then we've got to figure out an acceptable political solution.
answer: And if there has been a coup and there is no acceptable political solution?

question: What do you want? A good-bye kiss?
answer: Hey, Joe. Listen, I'll take care of him. Go ahead in, grab some coffee. We'll be back pretty quick. What's the matter with you? Forget how to open a car door? Jesus, you rich people.

question: I don't know if I can do this.
answer: There's nobody else I'd rather have going in there. Nobody else I'd trust Helen and the kids' lives to.

question: Take a left. We gave so much to get here. I don't know. Sometimes I think what the hell did we do it for?
answer: Because we knew we could do a better job than everyone else.

question: You know... I hate being called the brilliant one. The ruthless one. They guy who does the dirty work. The one everybody's afraid of. I hate it. I'm not smart, you know. And I'm not so ruthless.
answer: You're right about the smart part, but ruthless, well...

question: Slow down. Smell that?
answer: Smoke.

question: Just wanted to see for myself. They're burning their documents. They think we're going to war. G-d help us, Ken.
answer: I'll whistle up some luck for you. The friend.

question: Ambassador Dobrynin, we are aware that at this moment your missiles in Cuba are at the brink of operational readiness... They are a vital threat to my country. If launched, they would kill 80 million Americans. My brother, my friends, my countrymen and I cannot and will not permit those missiles to become operational. I promise you that.
answer: Then I fear our two nations will go to war. And I fear where war will lead us.

question: If the missiles do not become operational, if you remove the missiles, then there will be no war. At this moment, the President is accepting the terms of Secretary Khruschev's letter of Friday night. If the Soviet Union halts construction immediately, removes the missiles, and submits to U.N. inspection, the United States will pledge to never invade Cuba or aid others in that enterprise.
answer: If your Jupiter missiles in Turkey were removed also, such an accommodation could be reached.

question: The United States cannot agree to such terms under threat. Any belief to the contrary -- -- was in error.
answer: You want war...

question: However, while there can be no quid pro quo on this issue, the United States can offer a private assurance. Our Jupiter missiles in Turkey are obsolete, and have been scheduled for withdrawal for some time. This withdrawal should be completed within, say, six months. Of course, any public disclosure of this assurance would negate the deal and produce the most stringent denials from our government.
answer: This private assurance represents the word of the Highest Authority?

question: Yes.
answer: And it can be relayed beyond Comrade Khruschev's ears to the top circles of my government

question: Of course. Our pledge can be relayed to any government official Secretary Khruschev sees fit to satisfy. With the caveat that it is not made public in any way, shape or form. And we must have an answer tomorrow at the latest. I cannot stress this point enough.
answer: Tomorrow...

question: Tomorrow...
answer: Then you must excuse me and permit me to relay the substance of our discussion to my superiors. We have heard stories that some among your military men wish for war. You are a good man. Your brother is a good man. I assure you there are other good men. Let us hope the will of good men is enough to counter the terrible strength of this thing which has been put in motion.

question: Don't you understand?
answer: Understand what?

question: The sun came up today.
answer: Yeah.
